title: Gunman accused of killing five Capital Gazette employees is set to change his plea to guilty
text:
Jarrod Ramos, accused of killing five staffers at Maryland newspaper last year is set to plead guilty but not criminally responsible by reason of insanity

An attorney for the man accused of killing five Maryland newspaper employees last year told a court Monday that he will plead guilty but not criminally responsible by reason of insanity to the murders.

Attorney Katy O'Donnell said Jarrod Ramos intends to plead guilty to all 23 charges in the indictment, including five counts of first-degree murder, in connection with a shooting at the Capital Gazette newspaper in Annapolis in 2018.

O'Donnell's remarks came during a pretrial hearing in Annapolis just days before his trial is due to start.

Judge Laura Ripken still needs to accept the guilty pleas to make them official.

His plea means the case will skip the first phase of determining guilt and move to a second phase of determining whether he is criminally responsible.

Editorial page editor Gerald Fischman, 61, (left) and special publications editor Wendi Winters, 65, (right) were also killed

Five people were killed in the shooting, including (from left) writer John McNamara, 56, and assistant editor Robert Hiaasen, 59,

Ramos' lawyer Elizabeth Palan emphasized the portion of the video that shows one of the five victims killed - sales assistant Rebecca Smith, 34, (pictured) - trying to escape after she was shot

The 39-year-old Ramos had originally pleaded not guilty and not criminally responsible. The latter term is Maryland's version of an insanity defense.

Employees of the newspaper who attended the hearing held hands as the attorney addressed the court.

Ramos' plea is the latest turn in his long history with the newspaper.

Before the shooting, he had been accused of harassing the Capital Gazette's staff in connection with a defamation suit he filed against the newspaper in 2012 after it ran a column about his pleading guilty to harassing a former high school classmate who alleged he was stalking and harassing her. The suit was thrown out.

His anger at the newspaper began with an online harassment and stalking case stemming from late 2009 or early 2010.

The woman eventually went to police, and Ramos pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor harassment charge. The newspaper's story about the case touched off a tirade from Ramos.

Authorities say Ramos stormed the newspaper office in June 2018 with a shotgun and methodically killed Gerald Fisch­man, 61; assistant editor Rob Hiaasen, 59; sportswriter, reporter and editor John McNamara, 56; sales assistant Rebecca Smith, 34; and reporter Wendi Winters, 65. It was one of the deadliest attacks on journalists in U.S. history.

Police say they arrested Ramos after the shooting as he hid under a desk in the newsroom.

Surveillance video from the shooting doesn't show anyone getting shot, but it shows Ramos entering the building with a shotgun, flashes of gunshots and several victims trying to escape. Law enforcement officials are pictured at the scene after the tragedy on June 28, 2018

Editor Rick Hutzell (center) gives a speech to his staff on April 15, 2019, after the Capital Gazette won a special Pulitzer Prize citation for its coverage and courage in the face of a massacre in its own newsroom

Employees of the newspaper who attended the hearing held hands as the attorney addressed the court.

Anne Colt Leitess, the state's attorney prosecuting the case, described in a statement of facts how Ramos gave himself up to police.

'I surrender. I surrender. I'm your shooter,' Ramos said, according to Leitess' statement of facts, which she read in court.

Ramos' mental health had been a point of contention between defense attorneys and prosecutors as they prepared for his trial and he had earlier pleaded not criminally responsible, citing a mental disorder that kept him from understanding the illegality of his actions at the time of the shooting.

According to the state's attorney, jury selection would start Wednesday if the judge does accept his guilty plea. A hearing to determine whether Ramos is criminally responsible would begin in November.

The defense has argued that video of the June 2018 shooting inside the Capital Gazette's Annapolis newsroom is too graphic to be shown at his November trial. Employees are seen inside the newsroom one week after the horror attack in July 2018
description: Jarrod Ramos, 39, is accused of killing five staffers at a Maryland newspaper last year. He is to plead guilty but not criminally responsible by reason of insanity to all 23 charges in the indictment.
